Page.Title: Introduction to the Trade Practices Training Program

font.span:
In this lesson you will move through a number of information pages which will teach you about Trade Practices.
You will also be presented with scenario pages, where a situation will be described involving a number of fictitious characters. You will be asked questions which will test your understanding of Trade Practices.

These questions are not scored and your response is not recorded. Use the feedback provided to consolidate what you have learned during this lesson.
Click on the Quick Facts menu button above to view a summary of points covered in the lesson.

Picture.AltText: This is a picture of a monkey

Description.div: This lesson should take about 30 minutes. In this time, we will introduce you to the Trade Practices Act 1974 ("TPA").
At the end of the lesson you should have a clear understanding of:

ul.li: what the TPA is about;
the legal risks for you and your company;
the financial risks for you and your company;
your company's view on compliance with the TPA; and
what you should do if the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission ("ACCC") contacts you.

Description.div: The purpose of this generic trade practices training program is to alert users to some of the problems which might occur in their industry or area of operations. It does not contain targeted legal advice or a comprehensive tailored trade practices compliance program and you should seek specialist trade practices advice on particular issues of concern.

We will help you to apply your knowledge by asking you questions about a factual situation. These questions will not be scored. Please read the factual situation carefully and keep it in mind as you work through the lesson.
To get started, please click on the next button below.

TextGraphic.Description: This is some text on a text graphic control

Description.div: Imagine you work at the Single Mail, a rural newspaper. You have one main competitor, The Musical Recorder, another newspaper servicing the same area as the Single Mail.

Bob Blundstone is the Manager of the accounting and administration team at the Single Mail. He is a very diligent and honest worker and sometimes stays up all night to balance the books and compile reports for senior management.
Ms Adventure is the new office assistant at the Single Mail. She is enthusiastic and eager to please. Everyone comments on how friendly and pro-active she is.

Bob Blundstone receives a phone call from an ACCC investigations officer, Ms Query. Ms Query asks whether the Single Mail is aware that its recent newspaper advertisement states that the advertising rates of another newspaper, The Musical Recorder, are 10% higher than the advertising rates at the Single Mail. She says that the advertising rates at The Musical Recorder are actually less than at the Single Mail. Ms Query says that the advertisement was clearly wrong and may have misled the public.

div.strong: Consider this scenario while reading the next pages...

ul.li: promotes competition in the marketplace so that better outcomes are achieved for consumers ("competition law"); and
protects consumers against unfair practices and unsafe goods and services ("consumer protection law").

Description.div: The competition law provisions of the TPA treat anti-competitive behaviour in two different ways:

ul.li: Automatic breaches - behaviour that is automatically illegal without any assessment as to the actual or likely impact on competition in a relevant market.

Other breaches - behaviour that is tested by evaluating the market power of the participants, the reasons for their conduct and the resulting purpose or effect of their proposed or actual conduct on competition in a relevant market.

Page.Title: Automatic breaches: behaviour that is always illegal

Description.div: This category of behaviour is regarded as inherently anti-competitive and is automatically illegal. No competition assessment is made. It does not matter whether the behaviour would have or could have actually substantially lessened competition in a market. Thus, the behaviour of even the smallest market players is caught. Such conduct is only legal if it is "authorised" beforehand by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission ("ACCC").

It is like a speeding offence. If you exceed the speed limit, then the police will not accept any excuse and will issue you with a speeding ticket. In other words, no assessment is made as to whether your behaviour at the time poses a hazard to anyone or can be justified. It is the same with these offences which are automatically illegal.

div.strong: Accordingly these provisions in particular must be treated with great respect:

ul.li: Price Fixing (competitors agreeing price);
Collective Boycotts (competitors excluding customers, suppliers or other competitors);
Third Line Forcing (forcing someone else's products on your customers); and
Minimum Resale Price Maintenance (setting minimum prices).

Page.Title: Other breaches: tested by purpose or effect on competition or competitors

Description.div: The second type of behaviour prohibited by the competition law provisions requires an assessment of competition. Behaviour is only regarded as anti-competitive and unlawful where it has the purpose or likely effect of substantially lessening competition in a relevant market, given the market significance of those who undertake the conduct and those who may be affected by it, or where it is a misuse of market power because conduct is undertaken for one of three prohibited purposes.

To use a driving example again, this behaviour is like negligent driving. You are not a negligent driver until all the circumstances are considered and the nature and outcome of your behaviour is evaluated.

div.strong: These provisions of the TPA should also be treated with great respect:

ul.li: Misuse of Market Power (using power to damage competitors or competition);
Anti-competitive arrangements other than Collective Boycotts or Price Fixing (arrangements reducing competition); and
Most types of Exclusive Dealing (exclusive supply arrangements).

Description.div: The TPA also contains provisions which are aimed at protecting consumers and improving their position in their dealings in the marketplace. The consumer protection provisions deal primarily with misrepresentation, misleading or deceptive conduct, liability of manufacturers and importers of goods, GST price exploitation and a number of specific prohibited practices such as unconscionable conduct (which is also designed to protect small business). Some of these provisions are discussed in later modules.
Other provisions of the TPA, which are not dealt with in this material, deal with access to essential facilities, industry codes of conduct and telecommunications regulation.

Page.Title: Why should you comply with the TPA? What's in it for you?

Description.div: The competition and consumer protection laws apply to many aspects of the operations of your company. Understanding these rules will help your company and its employees to deal confidently with its customers and other businesses, and to compete in a way which does not breach the TPA.

A breach of the TPA may have very serious consequences for your company, and for you personally if you are involved in the breach. The TPA imposes significant penalties on companies and individuals. The courts regard breaches of the TPA very seriously.

ExtraInfo.Heading: Click here to see the penalties for breaching the TPA.

Description.div: The maximum penalty for each breach of the competition law provisions is:

ul.li: $10 million for a company, and
$500,000 for an individual.

Description.div: Note: The maximum penalties are expected to be increased in 2005 to the greater of $10 million or 3 times the gain from the contravention or 10% of the turnover of the group of companies to which the contravention company belongs.
The maximum penalty for each breach of the consumer protection law provisions (apart from section 52, misleading or deceptive conduct) is:

ul.li: $1.1 million for a company; and
$220,000 for an individual.

Description.div: There are proposals to increase these penalties.
The misleading or deceptive conduct provisions are enforced by injunctions and other orders. Persons injured by the conduct may also seek damages.
Your company, its directors and its employees are all potentially liable for breaches of the TPA.
As an employee of your company you could also incur an individual penalty. This may have to be paid by you, not by your company.

Also, you could be personally sued for damages by any person who suffers loss because of a breach. The courts also have power to make other orders. For example, a court can order that conduct be stopped or that certain things be done to remedy the conduct.

Where your company's conduct is caught by the TPA, the TPA also applies to directors and employees participating in any offending conduct. An individual is "involved" in a contravention, for example, by aiding, abetting, counselling, procuring or inducing a contravention, or by being knowingly concerned in or conspiring with another to effect a contravention. Attempted contraventions are also caught.

Apart from the significant penalty and other remedy consequences, and the costs and time involved in dealing with the issue, breaches of the TPA will jeopardise your company's reputation and goodwill.

ExtraInfo.Heading: Click here for some examples of how the courts have applied penalties for breaches of the TPA.

Internal.Title: ACCC v Roche Vitamins Australia Pty Ltd and Ors (2001)

Description.div: In February 2001, the Federal Court imposed record penalties on 3 vitamin manufacturers (Roche Vitamins Australia Pty Ltd, BASF Australia Ltd and Aventis Animal Nutrition Pty Ltd) after they admitted participating in a collusive arrangement in relation to supply in Australia of various vitamins used in the preparation of animal feed. The Australian arrangements were part of an international collusive arrangement entered into by the Roche, BASF and Aventis' overseas parent companies. Between 1994 and 1997, Australian representatives from the 3 companies at meetings or via telephone conferences agreed the prices at which the companies would supply the vitamins in Australia. A similar arrangement operated between Roche and BASF during 1997 and 1998.

The ACCC submitted to the Court that the conduct was "uniquely serious" as it involved local companies giving effect to global arrangements made by multinational corporate groups. In light of this and other factors (including the involvement of senior management in Australia, the market shares of the companies and the value of sales affected by the conduct), the Federal Court imposed fines of $15 million, $7.5 million and $3.5 million on Roche, BASF and Aventis respectively.

Internal.Title: ACCC v ABB Transmission and Distribution Ltd and Ors (2001)

Description.div: A number of manufacturers admitted to being involved in collusive arrangements from the early 1990s to 1999 regarding the supply of electrical transformers. Electrical utilities and large companies use transformers in the transmission of electricity. Transformers are usually custom made, with buyers calling for tenders. The manufacturers admitted having meetings where they decided which manufacturer would be allocated the tender. That company would later inform the others of the price it intended to quote, with the other companies agreeing to submit quotes at higher prices. The ACCC instituted proceedings against both the manufacturers and the company officers who gave effect to the arrangements.

The Federal Court imposed fines of $7 million on one manufacturer, Alstom Australia Ltd, and $150,000 on its Managing Director for being knowingly concerned in the contraventions, $4 million on Wilson Transformer Company, $3.5 million on AW Tyree (and $150,000 on its Managing Director), $5.5 million on Schneider, $8.5 million on ABB Power, $5.5 million on ABB Transmission and Distribution, $200,000 against the ABB Managing Director and a total of $145,000 on three other senior executives.

Internal.Title: ACCC v Tyco Pty Limited & Ors (1999)

Description.div: Tyco Australia Pty Ltd supplied fire alarm and fire protection systems in Brisbane and throughout Queensland. At regular meetings, representatives of Tyco and other fire protection companies agreed which tenders each company would win and the prices to be tendered for those contracts.
Tyco pleaded guilty to the conduct and the Federal Court imposed a total penalty of $4.7 million on the company. Four executives were also fined a total of $300,000.

Internal.Title: ACCC v FFE Building Services Limited (2003)

Description.div: In this case, FFE discovered through its trade practices compliance and training program that certain illegal conduct had occurred and voluntarily approached the ACCC to take advantage of its leniency policy.
The illegal conduct was in relation to fire protection tenders in Sydney and Newcastle and involved market sharing, price collusion and misleading or deceptive conduct.
FEE admitted the contraventions and the Federal Court imposed a penalty of $3.5 million on the Company. FFE's former State Manager in NSW was fined $50,000.
No penalties were imposed on FFE and its employees.

Note: The ACCC instituted court proceedings in 1999 alleging similar conduct in Queensland. The Federal Court imposed total penalties of $14.79 million and made orders for almost $600,00 in costs. That case involved 38 individuals and more than 20 companies.

Internal.Title: ACCC v Universal Music Australia Pty Ltd (2003)

Description.div: Warner Music and Universal Music were found to have breached the exclusive dealing provisions of the TPA when responding to the parallel importation of CDs by small business.
Universal and Warner were fined $1 million each. The executives of those companies were fined $45,000 each.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission ("ACCC") is the independent Federal statutory authority responsible for ensuring compliance with the TPA. The ACCC may seek pecuniary penalties at any time within 6 years of the date of contravention of the competition laws, and within 3 years of the date of breaches of consumer protection laws. Other remedies may be sought by the ACCC or by any other person, generally at any time within 6 years of the contravention.

If you want more information about the ACCC's role and activities, click here to look at its website.
Browsing the latest ACCC press releases will give you a better idea of the range of the ACCC's work.
The ACCC has extensive powers. It can:

ul.li: sue your company and its employees (sometimes without notice) (including you personally, if it suspects your company and you have breached the TPA);
compel you to attend its offices for interviews which can be used against you later in court; and

compel your company and its employees (sometimes without notice) to provide its business records, including emails and other confidential company documents, and answer questions concerning possible breaches of the TPA. In light of this, you should exercise particular care in the use and content of email communication with other employees (including reporting to your manager) as the ACCC may require you to produce copies.

Description.div: The ACCC has a Leniency Policy for Cartel Conduct aimed at encouraging corporations and their executives to disclose "hard core" cartel conduct. Immunity from prosecution is available for cartel participants who are the first to disclose the existence of a cartel and fully cooperate with the ACCC's investigations. The ACCC also has a general cooperation policy in relation to possible immunity or leniency for breaches of the cartel and other provisions of the TPA. You should promptly report suspected breaches of the TPA to your Manager or the Company Secretary.

Each of your competitors, customers, suppliers and agents may also bring an action against you for breach of the TPA. Consequently, it is important to make sure that all your dealings with these parties comply with the law.

div.strong: Now we will look at how you might deal with a potential Trade Practices situation...

Description.div: Do you remember the factual situation?

ExtraInfo.Heading: If not, click here for a reminder and then try answering the question below.

Description.div: Imagine you work at the Single Mail, a rural newspaper. You have one main competitor, The Musical Recorder, another newspaper servicing the same area as the Single Mail.

Bob Blundstone is the Manager of the accounting and administration team at the Single Mail. He is a very diligent and honest worker and sometimes stays up all night to balance the books and compile reports for senior management.
Ms Adventure is the new office assistant at the Single Mail. She is enthusiastic and eager to please. Everyone comments on how friendly and pro-active she is.

Bob Blundstone receives a phone call from an ACCC investigations officer, Ms Query. Ms Query asks whether the Single Mail is aware that its recent newspaper advertisement states that the advertising rates of another newspaper, The Musical Recorder, are 10% higher than the advertising rates at the Single Mail. She says that the advertising rates at The Musical Recorder are actually less than at the Single Mail. Ms Query says that the advertisement was clearly wrong and may have misled the public.

Answer.AnswerText: (a) "When we developed the advertisement I think we checked with The Musical Recorder and our summary of their advertising rates was correct";

Feedback.div: You are incorrect. The correct answer is (c).

If a representative from the ACCC contacts you, inform him or her that you are not authorised to provide the information requested and refer the inquiry immediately to your manager and to the company secretary with any information you have about it. While the policy of your organisation is one of cooperation, this should be after management reviews all relevant facts and receives legal advice.

Answer.AnswerText: (b) "We review our advertising materials regularly. I think our latest review indicated that the advertisement was correct. The Musical Recorder must have changed its position quite recently"; or

Feedback.div: You are incorrect. The correct answer is (c).

Always be careful to respond promptly to the ACCC, if authorised to do so, even if it is only to let them know of your progress. You should obtain the best information, both factual and legal, about the matter.

Your responses to the ACCC and actions you take to resolve any problem will influence the way in which the ACCC views you and your organisation. It is often difficult to correct an unfavourable impression once it has been made.
Business people sometimes think that the situation can be explained away. You should always remember that it is the ACCC's job to enforce the law, so speak to your Manager before answering.

Bob should speak to the staff member who developed the advertisement to ascertain whether its accuracy was checked at that time, whether it is in fact still current and correct, and whether the text contains any appropriate qualification or explanation as to the currency of the information. He should speak to his manager to discuss how the matter should be handled and report the contact immediately to the company secretary.

Answer.AnswerText: c) "I will look into the matter and get back to you".

Feedback.div: Now, how do we address the issue raised by the ACCC?

Bob should speak to the staff member who developed the advertisement to ascertain whether its accuracy was checked at that time, whether it is in fact still current and correct, and whether the text contains any appropriate qualification or explanation as to the currency of the information. He should inform his manager and report the matter immediately to the company secretary to discuss how the matter should be handled and obtain appropriate legal advice.

TextBox.Description: Do you remember the factual situation?

ExtraInfo.Heading: If not, click here for a reminder and then try answering the question below.

Description.div: Imagine you work at the Single Mail, a rural newspaper. You have one main competitor, The Musical Recorder, another newspaper servicing the same area as the Single Mail.

Bob Blundstone is the Manager of the accounting and administration team at the Single Mail. He is a very diligent and honest worker and sometimes stays up all night to balance the books and compile reports for senior management.
Ms Adventure is the new office assistant at the Single Mail. She is enthusiastic and eager to please. Everyone comments on how friendly and pro-active she is.

Bob Blundstone receives a phone call from an ACCC investigations officer, Ms Query. Ms Query asks whether the Single Mail is aware that its recent newspaper advertisement states that the advertising rates of another newspaper, The Musical Recorder, are 10% higher than the advertising rates at the Single Mail. She says that the advertising rates at The Musical Recorder are actually less than at the Single Mail. Ms Query says that the advertisement was clearly wrong and may have misled the public.

Bob telephones Ms Adventure, the Single Mail staff member responsible for developing the advertisement, to discuss her most recent review of the offerings of The Musical Recorder and the content of the advertisement.

Question.strong: What questions do you think he should ask her?

ul.li: When did we last check the advertising rates which The Musical Recorder offers?
How did we check?
Do we have a process to be notified of any change to The Musical Recorder's advertising rates?
How is up-to-date information conveyed to our personnel and to the public?
Do we put appropriate explanations in our advertisements alerting readers to check any subsequent changes with The Musical Recorder?

Feedback.div: You are looking at the right issues.

TextBox.Description: Do you remember the factual situation?

ExtraInfo.Heading: If not, click here for a reminder and then try answering the question below.

Description.div: Imagine you work at the Single Mail, a rural newspaper. You have one main competitor, The Musical Recorder, another newspaper servicing the same area as the Single Mail.

Bob Blundstone is the Manager of the accounting and administration team at the Single Mail. He is a very diligent and honest worker and sometimes stays up all night to balance the books and compile reports for senior management.
Ms Adventure is the new office assistant at the Single Mail. She is enthusiastic and eager to please. Everyone comments on how friendly and pro-active she is.

Bob Blundstone receives a phone call from an ACCC investigations officer, Ms Query. Ms Query asks whether the Single Mail is aware that its recent newspaper advertisement states that the advertising rates of another newspaper, The Musical Recorder, are 10% higher than the advertising rates at the Single Mail. She says that the advertising rates at The Musical Recorder are actually less than at the Single Mail. Ms Query says that the advertisement was clearly wrong and may have misled the public.
Bob discovers that Ms Adventure has deliberately misrepresented The Musical Recorder's advertising rates. Does this make the position worse?

ExtraInfo.Heading: Click here for some tips on how to answer the question.

Description.div: Even if Bob is able to satisfy the ACCC on this occasion that the matter might be resolved amicably, it is very important that he take the opportunity to correct the Single Mail's internal supervision processes to avoid repetition of similar problems. Ms Adventure should be counselled accordingly.
The ACCC monitors organisations to determine whether they have an appropriate "culture of compliance" with the TPA and whether they apply all lessons learnt to their commitment to compliance.

Bob must liaise with the Single Mail staff to ensure that this type of complaint cannot be made in future. This means ensuring that the correct review processes are in place and that the Single Mail's information processes do not allow for mistakes in the copy.

Even if the ACCC decides not to take any action, The Musical Recorder may still decide to sue both the Single Mail and Ms Adventure for any loss or damage it can show it suffered as a result of their conduct.

Question.strong: What action could the ACCC take in this situation?

Feedback.div: If you said that the ACCC can:

ul.li: Bring proceedings against the Single Mail and also the officer concerned for false and misleading conduct.
Require the Single Mail to produce all internal and external correspondence and notes relevant to the issue.
Interview all employees concerned.
Ask the court to impose penalties on the Single Mail and the officer.
Ask the court to restrain the use of the brochure and to order corrective advertising.
Ask the court to order the Single Mail and the officer to compensate The Musical Recorder for any loss or damage it has suffered.
All of the above.

Feedback.div: You are looking at the right issues.

If the advertisement is misleading, then whether or not Ms Adventure's conduct was deliberate, the law is broken. The deliberateness of her conduct will bring the conduct within the penalty provisions of the consumer protection laws. It will reflect poorly on the Single Mail and her when the court considers the appropriate penalty and remedies needed to deter repetition and to rectify the issue.

In addition (unless it is already covered by an order from the ACCC's case) The Musical Recorder might also sue the Single Mail and Ms Adventure for any loss or damage it can show it has suffered as a result.

Description.div: You should understand that compliance with the TPA is critical for all those involved in business.
You should also be aware that TPA problems do not arrive on your doorstep labelled "TPA Risk".
There are particular situations which will always expose you to a higher risk of contravention, and you should identify these and put in place strategies for minimising your risk.
Always promptly report suspected breaches of the TPA to your Manager or the Company Secretary.
Congratulations! You have completed your lesson.
Click the End Lesson button to exit the lesson.
